column16: Donation to underwrite the cost of the Blanton Museum of Art Gala at the UT Austin College of Fine Arts (not for attendance, donor declines all benefits). For exclusively public purposes.
column17: Per banking team, not for attendance and all benefits declined. Section 170(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code provides that the United States, the District of Columbia, any possession of the United States, any state, or any political subdivision of any of the foregoing, will constitute a qualified charitable grantee so long as the contribution or gift is made for exclusively public purposes. In addition, the longstanding position of the IRS has been that contributions or gifts to an instrumentality of a state or local government that are made exclusively for public purposes are deductible charitable contributions. The term "exclusively for public purposes" is not defined. However, there is no requirement that the contribution be for traditional governmental purposes.
